CHAPTER 19: THE CHALLENGE

Dawn, May 10, 1431 - Before Granada's Western Gate

The sun climbed above the Sierra Nevada, flooding the Vega de Granada with honey-gold light. Irrigation channels glittered like silver threads across the green fields. In the distance, Granada rose against the mountains—white walls, red towers, the Alhambra's fortress complex sprawling across its hill. From minarets across the city, the call to fajr prayer drifted through the morning air, hauntingly beautiful even to Christian ears.

But this morning, prayer competed with war drums.

Your army stretched across the plain in battle formation—ten thousand men deployed with the precision of months of campaigning. Infantry in the center, cavalry on the flanks, banners streaming in the morning breeze. The great crusade standard hung beside your position, the red cross vivid against white silk. Somewhere out in the fields, invisible among irrigation channels and olive groves, Don Rodrigo de Perea's thousand infantry lay hidden after seven cold hours of silence.

The trap was set. The Sultan thought he would spring an ambush. He had no idea you'd read his sealed orders.

You turned to your commanders gathered around you—the Master of Calatrava, Don Fadrique Enríquez, Captain Fernán, Sergeant García, Corporal Rodrigo. Three hundred heavy cavalry assembled behind you, the finest troops in your army. Fifty Guardian Company knights in their distinctive armor. One hundred fifty Calatrava cavalry, seasoned crusaders. One hundred frontier veterans who knew desperate fighting.

"Ready?" you asked simply.

Captain Fernán checked your armor one final time. White-painted steel, perfect fit, every strap secured. White surcoat with the red cross. Your father's sword at your hip: Non Nobis Domine, Sed Nomini Tuo Da Gloriam. "Ready, Your Majesty."

García moved to your left side, Rodrigo to your right. Their positions. Always.

The Master of Calatrava clasped your shoulder briefly. "God be with you, Your Majesty. We'll be right behind you."

You nodded, lowered the visor on your helmet, then thought better of it. You wanted them to see your face. You wanted the Sultan to know exactly who stood before his gates.

You removed the helmet entirely, handing it to a squire. Your hair caught the morning light.

"Forward," you commanded.

Three hundred horsemen moved across the plain toward Granada. Not at a charge, but at a measured walk—deliberate, controlled, inexorable. Hoofbeats rumbled like distant thunder. Mail jingled. Horses snorted in the morning cool. The crusade banner rippled overhead.

Behind you, your main army held position. Watching. Waiting.

Ahead, Granada's western wall loomed larger with each stride. Thirty feet of stone and mortar, crenellations bristling with defenders. You could see them now—hundreds of men crowded along the ramparts, pointing, shouting. Sunlight glinted off spear points and helmets. Archers nocked arrows but held them, waiting for orders.

The gate itself was massive—iron-reinforced timber, large enough for siege engines. And you knew what waited behind it. Twenty-five hundred to three thousand troops, assembled in the streets, officers briefed, weapons ready. Waiting for you to come within range. Waiting for the signal.

They think they're about to spring a trap.

You urged your horse forward, ahead of your escort. García and Rodrigo stayed close, but you moved into clear space where everyone could see you. Three hundred feet from the gate. Two hundred fifty. Two hundred.

Arrows could reach you now. You were within effective crossbow range. Your men shifted nervously, but held formation. They trusted you. They'd follow you into hell itself.

You reined in at roughly three hundred feet. Your escort fanned out into a loose arc behind you, a wall of steel and horseflesh. The crusade banner streamed in the wind.

For a moment, silence hung over the battlefield. Ten thousand Castilians watching from the plain. Thousands of Moors watching from the walls. The city holding its breath.

You stood in your stirrups, drew your father's sword, and raised it toward the gate. Your voice, trained by months of battlefield commands, carried clearly across the open ground:

"SULTAN MUHAMMAD! I, JUAN, BY THE GRACE OF GOD KING OF CASTILE, HAVE COME TO YOUR GATES TO FACE YOU, INFIDEL, AND DEMAND YOUR SURRENDER! SHOW YOURSELF BEFORE THESE SOLDIERS OF CHRIST!"

Your voice echoed off the walls. Somewhere inside, you knew, the Sultan heard. His vizier heard. His commanders heard. Every man assembled in those streets behind the gate heard the Christian king challenging their master at his own threshold.

You began riding slowly in tight circles before your escort, keeping your sword raised, visible to every defender on the walls:

"COME OUT AND FACE ME, COWARD! OR DO YOU HIDE BEHIND STONE WHILE BRAVER MEN WATCH? THE ARMY OF CHRIST STANDS BEFORE YOUR GATES! GOD HAS JUDGED BETWEEN US, AND YOU HAVE BEEN FOUND WANTING!"

Somewhere on the walls, a commotion. Figures moving. Arguing, perhaps. The Sultan's standard—green silk with golden Arabic script—flew from a tower near the gate.

You circled again, your white armor gleaming in the sunlight, impossible to miss:

"YOU CALLED FOR JIHAD, AND GOD ANSWERED—WITH YOUR ARMY'S DESTRUCTION AT ALCALÁ! YOU THOUGHT TO STAND AGAINST CHRIST'S ANOINTED, AND TEN THOUSAND OF YOUR MEN LIE DEAD! NOW I STAND AT YOUR THRESHOLD! WILL YOU HIDE LIKE A WOMAN, OR WILL YOU ANSWER LIKE A MAN?"

The personal insult. In both Christian and Moorish culture, devastating. No sultan could ignore such a challenge at his own gates, before his own troops, before his own people.

Behind you, your three hundred cavalry sat motionless, a steel wall. Farther back, your main army waited. And hidden in the fields, invisible to Granada's defenders, a thousand infantry lay ready.

The gate remained closed. But on the walls, the commotion was growing. Men shouting. Officers gesturing. And somewhere inside, you knew, the Sultan was making his decision.

GM Evaluation: The Challenge's Effectiveness

This is a critical moment requiring a roll. The Sultan's response will determine how the battle unfolds.

FACTORS IN YOUR FAVOR (Pros):

Calculated provocation perfectly executed: The challenge directly targets the Sultan's honor before his entire court, army, and populace—unbearable pressure in honor-based culture

Intelligence advantage: You know he's assembled the sortie force; this provocation aligns perfectly with his existing intentions

Tactical preparation: Counter-trap is expertly prepared with hidden flanking infantry, rapid-response cavalry, and overwhelming force in depth

Psychological momentum: Fresh from devastating victory at Alcalá (10,000 enemy dead), your army's confidence is sky-high while Granada is demoralized

Personal boldness: Removing helmet, exposing yourself to danger—this isn't empty rhetoric but genuine courage visible to all

Cultural understanding: The specific insults ("hide like a woman," "coward," questioning his manhood) strike at core values that transcend Christian/Muslim divide

Timing: Sultan has already committed to the sortie plan; this makes it almost impossible for him to back down without losing face

Visual impact: White armor, crusade banner, three hundred elite cavalry—magnificent and intimidating display

Strategic symbolism: Christian king at Muslim sultan's gates in heart of his own kingdom—historic, memorable moment

Recent defeats: Granada has lost every major engagement; Sultan desperately needs a victory to restore credibility

FACTORS AGAINST YOU (Cons):

Extreme personal danger: You're within effective missile range with limited cover; a lucky arrow or crossbow bolt could end the crusade

Numerical disadvantage at contact point: 300 escort vs. 2,500-3,000 sortie force—initial odds are terrible

Possible trap suspicion: Some of Sultan's advisors might smell a counter-trap and counsel caution

Gate bottleneck unpredictability: Deployment through gate will take time, potentially allowing phased withdrawal before full commitment

Sultan's desperation: He might refuse to engage, choosing to preserve forces rather than risk another defeat

Cultural differences: Sultan might not respond to European-style honor challenge exactly as expected

Home advantage: Granadan forces know terrain intimately, have walls at back for retreat, familiar ground

Alternative responses possible: Sultan could use wall-mounted artillery/crossbows instead of sortie, or wait you out

CUSTOM D100 TABLE: SULTAN'S RESPONSE

1-5: Catastrophic Refusal
Sultan recognizes trap and absolutely refuses to engage. Keeps gates closed, shouts defiance from walls but takes no action. Your challenge falls flat, making the dramatic approach look foolish. Must proceed with countryside devastation plan without the battle. Massive loss of face, though no casualties.

6-18: Cautious Defensive Response
Sultan deploys defensive forces only—archers, crossbowmen concentrate fire on your position from walls. Perhaps 300-500 troops emerge cautiously but don't fully commit. You take casualties (30-60 men) withdrawing but avoid disaster. Sortie force stays mostly uncommitted. Minor engagement, tactical draw.

19-35: Partial Sortie, Controlled Engagement
Sultan sends out 1,200-1,500 troops (half his force) to test your strength while keeping remainder in reserve. Disciplined, measured response. Battle ensues but not the overwhelming commitment you hoped for. Your counter-trap still works but less decisively. Moderate Castilian victory, 200-400 enemy casualties, you take 80-150 casualties. Sultan preserves core of force.

36-55: Standard Sortie as Planned
Sultan responds as his original plan dictated—refuses from walls, then launches full 2,500-3,000 troop sortie. Your counter-trap executes as designed. Flanking infantry emerges, cavalry responds in phases, you drive them back. Solid Castilian victory. 800-1,200 Granadan casualties, your forces take 150-300 casualties. Sultan's sortie force defeated but not destroyed. Clear tactical success.

56-72: Strong Commitment, Trap Springs Perfectly
Sultan takes the bait completely. Full sortie launches with excellent coordination, but your counter-trap execution is flawless. Hidden infantry appears precisely on time, cavalry hammer blow is devastating. Major Castilian victory. 1,400-1,900 Granadan casualties including many officers, your casualties 180-320. Sultan's sortie force shattered. Significant impact on Granada's will to resist.

73-85: Overcommitment Driven by Rage
Personal insults drive Sultan to abandon caution. He commits not just the sortie force but additional reserves (3,200-3,800 troops total), perhaps even leads personally or sends key commanders. Your trap becomes a massacre. Overwhelming Castilian victory. 2,000-2,800 enemy casualties, possibly including high-value prisoners. Your casualties 200-400. Granada's military capacity severely damaged.

86-94: Near-Total Destruction
Sultan's rage and desperation lead to catastrophic overcommitment. Nearly 4,000 troops pour through the gate in waves, discipline breaks down in fury to reach you. Your counter-trap achieves near-perfect execution. Enemy force routed with devastating casualties: 2,800-3,500 killed, hundreds captured including commanders. Your casualties 220-450. Granada's field force essentially destroyed. Political crisis in city probable.

95-100: The Sultan's Downfall
Complete disaster for Granada. Sultan either leads personally (and is killed/captured) or his sortie force is annihilated so thoroughly that political consequences are immediate. 3,200-4,000+ enemy casualties, mass rout, potential capture of Sultan or key members of royal family/court. Your casualties 250-500. Granada's capacity to resist field battles completely broken. Possible surrender negotiations within days. Campaign potentially shortened by months. Historic crushing victory.

You hold position, circling slowly on your horse before your three hundred cavalry. The morning sun climbs higher, warming your armor. Your escort sits motionless behind you, a wall of steel. The crusade banner snaps in the breeze.

Minutes pass. The walls remain crowded with defenders. You can see movement—messengers running, officers shouting orders, clusters of men arguing. The commotion centers around a tower near the gate where the Sultan's green standard flies.

Behind you, your main army waits in perfect silence. Ten thousand men watching their king stand alone before the enemy gate.

More time. Five minutes. Ten. The tension stretches. Some of your escort shift in their saddles. Captain Fernán edges his horse slightly forward, protective.

Then—movement on the tower.

A figure emerges onto the rampart directly above the gate. Even at this distance, you can see the richness of his robes—green silk with gold embroidery, a white turban with a jeweled clasp. The Sultan's ceremonial armor gleams beneath the robes. Two bodyguards flank him, shields raised protectively. A third man—vizier or senior commander by his dress—stands at his shoulder.

Sultan Muhammad IX looks down at you. For a moment, silence hangs over the battlefield.

Then his voice rings out—not in Arabic, but in Castilian. Accented, but clear enough for your men to understand:

"CHRISTIAN DOG! YOU DARE STAND AT MY GATES AND SPEAK OF SURRENDER? YOU, WHOSE GRANDFATHER DIED IN DEFEAT? WHOSE FATHER ACCOMPLISHED NOTHING? YOU ARE A BOY PLAYING AT WAR!"

The insults are calculated, meant to wound. Around you, your men tense. García's hand moves toward his sword hilt.

The Sultan continues, his voice rising:

"YOU WANT TO FACE ME? THEN FACE THE RIGHTEOUS FURY OF ISLAM! FACE THE WARRIORS OF GRANADA WHO WILL SEND YOU TO JOIN YOUR WEAK FATHER IN HELL! ALLAH AKBAR!"

The cry is taken up by thousands of voices on the walls: "ALLAH AKBAR! ALLAH AKBAR!"

And then—

The massive gates begin to swing open.

Not slowly. Not cautiously. They slam open with a boom that echoes across the plain, iron hinges shrieking. Behind them, you can see what you expected: a street packed with troops. Hundreds of men. Thousands. Infantry in the front ranks, spears leveled. Cavalry behind them, horses already moving. Moroccan troops in their distinctive armor. Officers shouting orders.

The street is a solid mass of armed men, and they're already surging forward.

War drums thunder from inside the city. Horns blare. The sortie force pours through the gate like a flood breaking through a dam—first dozens, then hundreds of troops spilling out onto the open ground before the walls. They deploy with practiced speed, infantry forming up, cavalry wheeling to the flanks.

You can see their numbers now. At least twenty-five hundred men, possibly more. The formations keep coming, streaming through that gate, officers directing them into battle order with shouts and signals.

Three hundred yards separate you from that growing mass of enemy troops.

Behind you, Captain Fernán's voice is urgent but controlled: "Your Majesty—"

The Moorish cavalry on the enemy flanks is already moving. Not charging yet, but advancing at a trot, beginning to spread wide to envelope your position. The infantry presses forward in the center, a bristling wall of spears and shields.

You can hear the shouts now—individual voices amid the roar. Officers directing troops. Men calling on God. The thunder of boots and hooves.

The sortie force continues to deploy, but the forward elements are already committed. Perhaps a thousand troops clear of the gate now, more still coming. They're moving toward you.

"BACK!" you shout. "TO THE RALLY POINT!"

Behind you, war drums thunder. The Moorish sortie pours through the gate—a river of steel and flesh. Infantry in the front, spears bristling. Cavalry wheeling wide on both flanks, beginning their envelopment.

The March to Loja - Day One, May 27th

The column departs Alcalá at dawn. Nineteen thousand troops, five bronze bombards, two hundred wagons. The crusade banner leads the way, your white armor visible at the head of the main body.

The first hours go well. The road is decent, the weather clear. The artillery moves at its steady pace—slow but manageable. The oxen strain against their harnesses, the massive bronze guns creaking on their carriages. Pietro Calabrese rides alongside his precious bombards, watching every wheel turn, every stress point on the carriages.

By mid-morning, the vanguard is eight miles ahead of the artillery. The column has stretched to nearly three miles long—impossible to defend every point simultaneously, but the cavalry screens are alert and professional.

First Contact - Late Morning

A messenger gallops back from the vanguard. "Your Majesty! Guerrillas ahead—sixty to eighty raiders blocking the road at a river crossing. They've burned the bridge."

You ride forward with Captain Fernán and a company of cavalry. The scene is clear when you arrive: a stone bridge over a tributary stream, partially collapsed. The wooden deck has been torched, stones pulled down. On the far side, Moorish light cavalry watch from a safe distance—maybe seventy men, armed with bows and javelins.

The stream isn't deep, but it's wide enough and the banks steep enough that the artillery and wagons will have difficulty crossing without the bridge.

Don García López de Padilla, commanding the vanguard, has already deployed troops. "We can ford it with the cavalry and infantry, Your Majesty. But the guns and wagons need a better crossing. We'll have to repair the bridge or find an alternative ford."

You order the vanguard across to secure the far bank. The infantry splashes through the stream, shields up against arrows from the distant raiders. A few men take arrows—one killed, four wounded—but the vanguard establishes a defensive position on the far side. The guerrillas fade back into the hills rather than face your force.

But the artillery is stuck. Pietro examines the bridge and shakes his head. "Need to rebuild the deck, Your Majesty. Three hours minimum, maybe four."

There's no choice. Engineers and work parties are brought forward. Timber is cut from nearby trees. Under heavy guard—the guerrillas are still out there—the bridge is repaired. The work takes four and a half hours.

It's mid-afternoon before the artillery begins crossing. Each gun must be taken over carefully, oxen straining, men pushing. One bombard's wheel catches on a stone and nearly tips—Pietro screams orders, men throw their weight against the carriage, and disaster is barely avoided.

The crossing is complete by evening. You've covered only twelve miles—half the expected distance for the first day.

Night Camp - May 27th

The army camps in open country, still ten miles from Loja. Defensive perimeter established, guards posted heavily. Everyone knows the guerrillas are out there, watching.

The Master of Calatrava reviews the day with you. "The bridge burning was coordinated, Your Majesty. They knew our route and our timing. There are more of them operating in this area than the scouts reported."

"Can we reach Loja tomorrow?" you ask.

"If nothing else goes wrong," he says. "But I suspect they're not done with us."

Day Two, May 28th - The Road to Hell

The march resumes before dawn. Everyone is alert, tense. The road ahead winds through increasingly rough terrain—rocky hills, narrow passages. Perfect ambush country.

Morning - The Canyon Attack

Around mid-morning, the road enters a narrow defile between two hills. The vanguard is through, but the main column and artillery are committed to the passage when war cries erupt from both sides.

Guerrillas—perhaps a hundred men—appear on the heights and loose arrows and javelins down into the column. They're not trying to stand and fight—just hit and fade, inflict casualties, and disappear before your cavalry can reach them.

The attack focuses on the supply train. Arrows rain down on the wagons. Oxen bellow and panic. Drivers are hit. One wagon catches fire from a flaming arrow—men rush to extinguish it while under continued fire.

Your flanking cavalry spurs up the hillsides to drive off the attackers, but the terrain is steep and rocky. By the time they reach the heights, most of the guerrillas have melted away. A few are caught and killed, but most escape.

The damage: Eight soldiers dead, fifteen wounded. Three wagon drivers killed. Four wagons damaged, one destroyed. Two oxen dead, five injured. And worst of all—one of the artillery carriages took a hit. A javelin struck one of the oxen pulling a bombard. The animal panicked, veered sideways, and the massive gun lurched. The carriage's axle cracked.

Pietro is beside himself. "God damn them! Three hours to repair, maybe more. And we're exposed here!"

The column is halted in the defile while repairs are made. Guards deployed on the heights. Everyone scanning for another attack. The engineers work frantically, but replacing an axle on a two-ton gun carriage takes time.

Two more guerrilla probes during the repair work—arrows from distance, quickly driven off by your archers, but enough to wound six more men and kill another ox.

The repair is completed by early afternoon. The column moves forward again, but now everyone is jumpy, exhausted from constant vigilance.

Casualties so far: 16 killed, 36 wounded

Afternoon - The Ambush on the Artillery

The worst comes in mid-afternoon. The terrain opens up somewhat—rolling hills, scattered olive groves. The artillery is moving through a relatively flat section when a larger force hits.

Seventy to eighty guerrillas, this time more organized and aggressive. They strike from an olive grove directly at the artillery column itself. Not hit-and-run this time—a genuine assault attempting to reach the guns.

The guards react immediately, forming a protective wall around the bombards. Fierce fighting erupts—hand-to-hand combat within fifty yards of the guns. You spur forward with your household guard, Garcia and Rodrigo at your sides.

The fighting is brutal but brief. The guerrillas are brave but outnumbered and outmatched once your cavalry reinforcements arrive. They're driven off after maybe ten minutes of combat, leaving thirty dead behind. But they achieved their purpose—more delays, more casualties, more exhaustion.

Your losses: Nineteen soldiers killed, twenty-three wounded. And Pietro reports that during the fighting, one of the bombard's wheels was damaged—not destroyed, but weakened. "It'll hold, Your Majesty," he says grimly, "but we need to move slowly. Any hard jolt could break it."

Which means the artillery pace slows even further.

Evening - The Crossing

By late afternoon, the column reaches another obstacle—a river crossing, this one wider and deeper than the morning's stream. The bridge here is intact, but it's old and narrow. The bombards must cross one at a time, and each crossing must be done with extreme care.

The process is agonizingly slow. Test the bridge. Cross the first gun—fifteen minutes of careful movement, oxen straining. Position it on the far side. Bring up the second gun. Repeat.

During the second gun's crossing, the weakened wheel that was damaged in the afternoon attack finally gives way. The carriage lurches, men shout, the gun tilts dangerously. For a terrifying moment it looks like it will crash through the bridge, but Pietro's crew manages to stop it. Emergency repairs on the bridge itself. Another two hours lost.

It's full dark by the time the last elements of the column cross the river. You're still five miles from Loja—too far to reach tonight.
